div.p: In the year 1550, on the 5th of April, from Frankfurt am Main.

Greetings. I received your letter, most esteemed Mr. Bullinger. I do not know where Florian has gone. Mr. Johannes a Lasco is staying in Bremen and has not yet been to Poland, as a citizen of Bremen known to me has reported; if you wish to write to him, I will take care of it diligently. It is true that Florian bought books from me, which he left in Antwerp.

I am not returning the letters; I will keep them; perhaps he will come or eventually indicate where he has gone. I give great thanks for the books sent to me; I will share them with a friend who is sending these to you; I ask that you convey your opinion and mind to him, so that he may finally be freed from doubt. I myself will offer your book to the senior archbishop and my most esteemed brother; both are still in good health. I will also offer your works to Caesar. I am surprised that Mr. Montius has sent nothing to you; I intend to remind him in my letters. They say the dispute between the French and the English has been resolved; nevertheless, the matter of religion proceeds. Caesar is preparing a journey to Germany, well-equipped with military forces. So far, being involved in various matters, I have not been able to send more detailed letters; if someone else comes along, I will write more diligently. Offer all my diligence to Mr. Gesner; I have sent letters to our doctors; I will send a response from Cologne as soon as possible. In the meantime, may you and all yours be well, and use me as your own. Hastily.
Your most obedient Johann Birckmann wrote. To the most esteemed Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, my esteemed lord and friend. In ZÃ¼rich.
